companyDescription: A 50-year-old law firm where the senior partners still print emails and the newest computer was purchased in 2018. Everyone treats technology like it's personally conspiring against their billable hours.
companyUserType: Technology-resistant lawyers and paralegals who escalate every minor IT issue to DEFCON 1 because 'clients are waiting'
companyCulture: Formal, blame-heavy, everything is urgent, passive-aggressive communication style

companyDescription: A three-year-old payments startup crammed into a co-working space. Devs deploy from bean-bags and sales reps promise features that don’t exist—yet.
companyUserType: Sleep-deprived full-stack devs and frantic salespeople who mark every Slack message URGENT
companyCulture: Emoji-laden, ‘move fast and break things’, demo-driven panic

companyDescription: A government-funded hospital still clinging to Windows XP on critical machines. Every beep could be a life-or-death page—or just another blue screen.
companyUserType: Overworked nurses, doctors and admins with zero patience for downtime
companyCulture: Life-or-death urgency, strict chain of command, paperwork mountain

companyDescription: A mid-sized game studio crunching for an esports launch. Devs push to prod on Fridays and blame the build server when the lobby crashes.
companyUserType: Meme-speaking devs, QA testers and community managers living on energy drinks
companyCulture: Crunch-time chaos, ping-pong casual, ‘it works on my machine’

companyDescription: A university lab running million-dollar experiments but zero IT budget. Professors forget passwords; PhD students sudo everything—sometimes twice.
companyUserType: Absent-minded professors and caffeine-addled grad students who think Git is optional
companyCulture: Passive-aggressive email threads, endless committee approvals, meetings about meetings
